properties.artist_bio: Pascal Paquette produces site- and context-specific works using painting, design, graffiti, street art and photography. His  work has been commissioned, published and exhibited internationally and locally, notably at the Museum of Contemporary Canadian Art (MOCCA), the Art Gallery of Ontario (AGO), Canadian Heritage as well as Art Basel (Switzerland), Art Basel Miami, FIAC (Paris, France), Art Chicago (USA), Art Cologne (K├╢ln, Germany) and Scope (London, UK). The Ontario Arts Council, British Arts Council, European Cultural Fund, Open Society Foundation and Toronto Arts Council have all supported his projects. He currently lives in Toronto, Canada with his wife and three children.
properties.description: This mural reflects the vibrancy of Kensington Market through a mixture of shapes and colours.

properties.artist_bio:
Sean Martindale is an internationally recognized, award winning interdisciplinary artist and designer based in Toronto, Canada. His interventions activate public spaces to encourage engagement, and often focus on ecological and social issues. His playful works suggest alternate possibilities for existing spaces, infrastructures, and materials found in urban environments. Frequently, he uses salvaged goods in unexpected ways that prompt conversation.

Among other notable projects, he was the lead artist on the Community Rising, the tallest mural in the world from 2013 to 2018 (now the second tallest), the result of a community project in St James Town, Toronto, with local youth, STEPS and the Toronto Muralists. Martindale has been the lead artist for a number of the GTAΓÇÖs largest mural projects. He continues to work closely with communities and organizations big and small; including partners such as Harbourfront Centre, the Art Gallery of Ontario, and the City of Toronto.

Martindale holds an MFA from the Interdisciplinary Masters of Art, Media and Design program at OCAD University in Toronto, and a BDes in Communication Design from Emily Carr University in Vancouver. He was the Decennial Hancock Lecturer at the University of TorontoΓÇÖs Hart House, where his presentation was broadcast by TVO for their Big Ideas series. He is a recipient of the prestigious Artist Prize from Toronto Friends of the Visual Arts, numerous grants at municipal, provincial, and federal levels, and a Chalmers Arts Fellowship from the Ontario Arts Council. Martindale was profiled for the first episode of CBCΓÇÖs Great Minds of Design, and his works have been featured digitally and published in traditional media around the world in multiple languages. His works have been exhibited publicly in many cities across the globe.

Recently, Martindale was Harbourfront CentreΓÇÖs inaugural Visual Artist-in-Residence, and alongside his collaborator JP King, was also the first Artist-in-Residence with the City of Toronto, Solid Waste Management Services.

-------------

ΓÇó	While I continue to be interested in traditional mural forms, I am also excited to keep exploring other media/materials in the public realm, spearhead new practices, and explore diverse approaches to community engagement. As well, I am interested in potentially growing other areas of my practice, and taking on more roles in related areas such as project coordination, program development, and consulting.
properties.description: Created by youth from the Lawrence Heights community who were mentored by two Toronto street artists, "Love or Love" communicates a sentiment of compassion and determination as the neighbourhood evolves.
properties.title: Sean Martindale and Joshua Barndt

properties.artist_bio: Through his artistic journey Rob Matejka has embraced art as a medium for positive social intervention and enjoys animating the communities and people he works with - making art accessible to all through; workshops, mentoring, and adding to the growing outdoor public gallery. Rob has been an arts educator and mentor for over 12 years - having worked with organizations across Toronto such as; Lakeshore Arts, Mural Routes, TDSB, The Toronto Public Library, VIBE Arts, and more. Rob enjoys using murals to create spaces we enter and experience physically - while coordinating large scale projects engaging large numbers of community members to beautify communities and build community pride.
properties.description: The theme of "re-foresting" is depicted in a series of birch tree-related artwork in an area known as 'Birchcliff', along the strip of Kingston Road between Warden Avenue and Birchmount Road.
properties.title: Rob Matejka and Elaine Teguibon

properties.title: Jennifer Rogers

properties.artist_bio: Jim Bravo was born in Ecuador, South America in 1973. He is a graduate of The Ontario College of Art and Design University where he majored in Fine Art and studied monumental & public art. Bravo has been active in the street/public art arena since his 2006 graduation, completing several city-funded murals and an array of community engagement art projects.  Through his affiliation with various local arts organizations he has gained vast experience as an arts mentor for at-risk youth initiatives. Bravo is a 4 time award winning painter and muralist and he lives and works in the city of Toronto

properties.artist_bio:
MONICA WICKELER
As a trained visual artist who has worked in the large scale painting industry in Toronto for many years, in outdoor advertising as a mural artist and in the film and television industry as a scenic artist, Monica Wickeler has found a love of community and public art. As well as painting community murals in playgrounds, on wading pools and in pedestrian laneways, she has recently enjoyed working with students to inspire them to approach large scale paintings in their own community and taking ownership and pride in who they are and in their neighborhoods.
ARTISTIC STATEMENT
I have always been inspired by the newest STREET/PUBLIC artist projects around the world. When I start a project my sketches will often be uploaded and worked on digitally to see how my ideas respond to the space it will be painted on I can digitally mock up and idea and can easily share it with the client. Once at the wall producing the work, that amazing feeling of working in the public eye kicks in and the getting feedback from pedestrians is always an inspiration. Recently I have been using a combination of brushwork and aerosol painting techniques and I am thrilled with the vibrancy of color and effects produced. Finding the connection between the visual landscape and the images the community connects with is my biggest goal during my design process.
properties.description: The Bell Box Murals project has transformed utility cabinets into works of art. This piece is a colourful interpretation of a historical photograph of the old Coxwell TTC station.
properties.title: Monica Wickeler

properties.artist_bio: Mike Parsons is a professional artist living in Toronto. I work exclusively with black and white images sing a combination of comic book illustration, graffiti street art and abstract images. Thematically my artworks explore the interrelationships between man, nature and technology primarily from an urban perspective. The goal of my work is express a positive optimistic warning towards progress and society. My work is playful yet insightful in order to appeal to audiences of all ages. I focus on live painting performances and street art because I believe public artworks have the most impact an offer the best opportunity to initiate dialogue. I worked as a fully licensed street artist from 2005-2009 where I created live murals at various locations across Toronto. Since that time I have become a full time muralist working across Canada and internationally. Notable clients include HudsonΓÇÖs Bay Co., Scotiabank, Converse, Dr. Martens, Waterloo University, UofT, Thyssenkrupp Canada, A.G.O. StreetARTToronto.

properties.artist_bio:
Dan Bergeron is a public artist who employs a range of styles, themes and materials to activate and explore the meaning of our shared public spaces. The shape, texture and location of a site and its history or current uses dictate the form and content of his projects. DanΓÇÖs public installations aim to open a dialog with viewers, promoting engagement through both intimate familiarity and wonder at the unexpected.

Dan has created public art projects for municipalities across Canada (Toronto, Mississauga, Ottawa, Gaspe, Calgary, Richmond), working in both two-dimensional mediums (murals, photo-based wheat pasting) and three dimensional sculpture. He has also been commissioned by the AGO, MOCA Toronto, the ROM and corporate clients Nike, Converse and Vespa.
properties.description: This ground mural highlights Evergreen's history as the former Don Valley Brick Works Factory and brings to life the buried archaeological resources that lie below the surface.

properties.artist_bio:
Visual Artist

Christiano De Araujo is a self-taught artist who was born in An├ípolis, Goi├ís, Brazil. His earliest memory as a child is the moment when he discovered his love of art. As a toddler, he remembers picking up a crayon that his older sister had left behind. When she found that Christiano had taken it, she grabbed it away from him, but in that short amount of time, he had fallen in love with colours and the ability to create.

His love of art and his talent for the drawing were evident when he was a student in school. His first passion was comics and cartoons and at age 12 he drew his first comic strip.

In his late teens, Christiano began working for BrazilΓÇÖs highly circulated newspaper, Di├írio da Manh├ú, doing editorial cartoons and illustrations. He also continued to work for other local newspapers and magazines. Realizing that he wanted more opportunities than he could have in Brazil, Christiano chose to immigrate to Canada.

His first years in Canada were a struggle. Early on, he landed a job as a Bricklayer, which he did for a number of years. Christiano confronted his weaknesses and discovered his strengths, learned to laugh at his hardships, quickly moving on. He was able to overcome any adversities with a determination to succeed and a desire to make himself a better man. This led to his artwork being published in numerous magazines and newspapers in Toronto.

He also credits his success to a spiritual awakening that he had through meditation and self-hypnosis. It gave him clarity and focus. This experience gave him more confidence and the ability to control his emotions and himself. Christiano devotes much of his life to his art. His endeavours include drawing, oil and acrylic painting, airbrushing, cartooning and sculpting. He is an artist by trade, finds art fun and likes to explore new media and innovated techniques.

Christiano currently resides in Toronto, Canada. He is the founder of Toronto Artists Studio, a studio of visual artists, painters, digital artists and sculptors who design and produce murals and visual communication projects for audiences on a small and grand scale.

At the present moment, this very momentΓÇª Christiano is enjoying the wonderful interaction between the mind and the universe. This infinite universe in which we are all one!

properties.artist_bio: Amir Akbari is a Greater Toronto Area (GTA) based Visual Artist, Educator, Community Advocate and Entrepreneur.   In 2002, he enrolled in OCAD University where he would go on to complete a Bachelors of Fine Arts with a focus on Drawing and Painting.  In 2003, Amir led his first community mural art project working with Urban Art Toronto.  The following year, he took on his first role with Street Art (then Graffiti Transformation Project) as the lead artist with Lamp Community Health Centre.  That project would be a launching pad for his eventual artistic and professional career.From 2003 to 2010 Amir continued to work with various community organizations and charities as an artist facilitator, youth works and educator.  He would go onto complete over 30 public murals throughout this time, working with and mentoring hundreds of youth across the GTA.In 2010 Amir founded Behind the Line with the purpose of providing existing support structures within the community with creative and artistic support.  Behind the Line has since worked closely with multiple organizations to enhance their arts programming and creative reach, from curriculum development, programming consultation and arts integration strategies.In the summer of 2019, Amir completed his largest mural production, the Susan Street Mural at 3847 Lawrence Ave. East.  This would be his 6th Street Art Partnership Project with the Boys & Girls Club of East Scarborough and his 3rd partnership with Toronto Community Housing.  The large 14 story mural is the crowning achievement of his artistic journey as a community and mural artist.  Focused on creating designs that reflect, represent and inspire the communities that he is working with, this mural is a celebration of the collaborative and uplifting nature of public murals funded by Street Art Toronto.His work is rooted in the belief that self-expression can have a lasting impact on the development and growth of young people and their communities, and that there is a disproportional disadvantage across the board for those that face multiple barriers with accessing the arts.   He hopes to fill this void through innovative arts strategies, collaborative mural projects and local community partnerships.
properties.description: This project celebrates the dynamic and thriving local community and highlights the importance of belonging through various collapsing and reconstructed shapes and images of local landmarks and daily interactions.
properties.organizations: Boys & Girls Club of East Scarborough
properties.title: Amir Akbari

His interventions activate public spaces to encourage engagement, and often focus on ecological and social issues. His playful works suggest alternate possibilities for existing spaces, infrastructures, and materials found in urban environments. Among other notable projects, he was the lead artist on the Community Rising, the tallest mural in the world from 2013 to 2018 (now the second tallest), the result of a community project in St James Town, Toronto, with local youth, STEPS and the Toronto Muralists. properties.artist_bio:
At the tender age of nine, Toronto-based illustrator Adrian Hayles discovered the expressive
nature of the visual arts. With his continued artistic development, illustration became his
deepest passion and talent. His desire to learn and absorb from his surroundings led him on a
personal creative journey. As a graduate of the Graphic Design program at Humber College
with over 10 years of working experience behind him, Adrian has established his place in
TorontoΓÇÖs modern art community. His style is provocative and inspiring and defies
categorization. Blurring the lines between graffiti and ultra realism, AdrianΓÇÖs voice and vision is
instantly identifiable. His works include countless portraits and illustrations for various
magazines and collaborations with the City of Toronto to develop murals for vacant community
spaces. In the past Adrian has painted complete buildings and city blocks, designed award
winning video games and animated television shows. He has also successfully developed and
filed a functioning patent for the Stud Horse Foldable Drawing Bench and is the Principal and
Founder of Behind the Front Visual Arts Studio.
properties.description: This mural creates a playful and inviting island and makes the intersection come alive by depicting a sandy beach and 3-dimensional waves around the flowers beds and street other furniture on the traffic 'island'.
properties.title: Adrian Hayles

properties.description: The theme of "re-foresting" is depicted in a series of birch tree-related artwork in an area known as 'Birchcliff', along the strip of Kingston Road between Warden Avenue and Birchmount Road. This mural also depicts houses on the bluffs.
properties.title: Emily Harrison

properties.description: The theme of "re-foresting" is depicted in a series of birch tree-related artwork in an area known as 'Birchcliff', along the strip of Kingston Road between Warden Avenue and Birchmount Road.
properties.title: Anthony Delacruz

properties.description: Several planter boxes along Queen Street West were transformed into works of art. This piece depicts an old man feverishly painting.
properties.title: Bruno Smoky

properties.description: This collection of panels depicts a community member at work and at play.
properties.title: Rocky Lawrence Green

properties.artist_bio: ΓÇÿElicserΓÇÖ Elliott explores narrative structures and new surfaces through the lens of more than a decade spent in the global graffiti community. A distinctive character-based practice, the work of Elicser is highly visible in cities throughout Canada, South America and South Africa. Known for his intuitive ability to capture the essence of a subject. Elicser Elliott leads the charge in the character-based movement in Toronto and was voted ΓÇÿBest Local Graffiti ArtistΓÇÖ by NOW Magazine for 2011 through 2014. His work was recently featured at the Institute for Contemporary Culture at the Royal Ontario Museum, the McMichael Canadian Art Collection, the Art Gallery of Ontario and at mural festivals in Hawaii and New York.
properties.description: This mural depicts and celebrates historic Church Street entertainers.
properties.title: Nadijah Robinson and Elicser

properties.artist_bio: Artist BiographyMargarita Alex Flores was born in Mexico City. A self-taught artist, her career has taken her across North America: El Paso, Texas, San Francisco, California, San Miguel de Allende, Mexico and Toronto, where she resides.She is an eco-feminist and social justice activist fighting for women rights, trans women and LGTBQ humans rightsAlex moved to Toronto, Canada in the spring of 2001.In 2014 she painted a mural for world pride, she also participates in painting a piano for the Installation in the Panam games 2015 representing Mexico in ΓÇ£Play me I am yoursΓÇ¥As a visual artist, Alex has worked in a variety of mediums: acrylics, wood, mosaics, and recyclable objects. She graduated as a teacher in 1988, in Mexico City.she is as well as an independent film-maker.Alex can be reached at416 902 0325http://www.alexfloresarte.comalexarte@sympatico.ca
properties.description: This bright and colourful mural celebrates women throughout the world.
properties.title: Alex Flores

properties.description: The Bell Box Murals project has transformed utility cabinets into works of art. This piece depicts diverse faces surrounded by organic foliage.
properties.title: Shayona Panth

properties.artist_bio: Jerry Silverberg is a multi-disciplinary artist and an educator.  He has worked primarily as a print maker showing his work in galleries and cafes in around the city as well as internationally. he has illustrated for The Globe and Mail, Walrus Magazine and his work has appeared in The New York Times. Since 2011 he has completed several Light Box murals and Bell Box murals in various locations throughout the city. He has also participated with INTER-NOS, a bi annual mural project in Santiago de Cuba
properties.description: The Bell Box Murals project has transformed utility cabinets into works of art. One side of this box depicts a cyclist in a park and the other side depicts semi-abstract images of doves, children, and flowers.
properties.title: Michael Nguyen and Jerry Silverberg

properties.description: This mural depicts the natural and First Nations context of the area and promotes environmental preservation by incorporating the area's three distinct eco-systems and animals that historically thrived (but not longer live) in the area.
properties.organizations: Native Child and Family Services of Toronto
properties.title: Isaac Weber, Rawn Razor, Brad Ladeour, and Lindsey Lickers

properties.description: This large mural attempts to blur the line between ΓÇ£highΓÇ¥ and ΓÇ£lowΓÇ¥ culture, critiques consumerism, and emphasizes audience interpretation.
properties.title: FAILE

properties.description: 16 murals on garage doors in the laneway behind homes on the south side of Dundas St West (facing Trinity Bellwoods Park) were painted with various colourful designs.
properties.title: Multiple artists, lead by artist Cruz1

properties.artist_bio:
I would like to work with StART because I have a history of working on public and community-engaged mural projects and programs, many of which have been supported and in partnership with StART. I believe in the values of the StART programs and have experienced the dedication of the team to carrying out these values through supporting and partnering.

I am a visual artist passionate about arts engagement and education, collaborative art making, and murals. These practices bridge my background from a Bachelor of Fine Art in Drawing & Painting from OCAD University and a Community Arts Practice Certificate from York University. Since 2011, I have worn many ΓÇÿhatsΓÇÖ in the mural, art and community arts field; from artist, arts educator, facilitator, curator, arts administrator and project manager. I have had the opportunity to work and learn from these experiences, building adaptability and flexibility through working in unique situations including libraries, schools, art galleries, community centres, seniors centres, skate parks, abandoned storefronts (you name it!). I have built a strong rapport working with many artists and arts organizations such as Mural Routes, Vibe Arts, Nuit Blanche, Lakeshore Arts, Platform A, Scribble me Silly, Arts Etobicoke and East End Arts. In particular, I have worked closely with Mural Routes since 2011, as Program Coordinator, Facilitator, Curriculum Coordinator, and Program Director, with a focus on mentorship and the Mural Art Learning Institute programs.

My creative processes for involving community and youth in projects within their own neighbourhoods are based in facilitation style that creatively employs storytelling, brainstorming, and playful art techniques like collage to encourage conversations, confidence and to bring many ideas together into action. It gives me great joy to facilitate consultation, design, art making and mural making to bring community members together to reflect and re-imagine their neighbourhood. I love any opportunity to nurture participantsΓÇÖ creative abilities and create a safe space for exploration and connection through visual arts and storytelling. I see art as a tool for exploring themes, beginning conversation, gathering patterns and beginning important dialogue. Mural consultation and participation offers a space where artists and community members alike can share, exchange, grow and work together.
properties.description: This legacy mural depicts the people and activities of the Taste of Lawrence Festival, a celebration of international food, music, and culture.
properties.title: Jennifer Moyer and Tara Dorey

properties.address: Park Lawn Rd & Lake Shore Blvd W
properties.artist_bio:
MONICA WICKELER
As a trained visual artist who has worked in the large scale painting industry in Toronto for many years, in outdoor advertising as a mural artist and in the film and television industry as a scenic artist, Monica Wickeler has found a love of community and public art. As well as painting community murals in playgrounds, on wading pools and in pedestrian laneways, she has recently enjoyed working with students to inspire them to approach large scale paintings in their own community and taking ownership and pride in who they are and in their neighborhoods.
ARTISTIC STATEMENT
I have always been inspired by the newest STREET/PUBLIC artist projects around the world. When I start a project my sketches will often be uploaded and worked on digitally to see how my ideas respond to the space it will be painted on I can digitally mock up and idea and can easily share it with the client. Once at the wall producing the work, that amazing feeling of working in the public eye kicks in and the getting feedback from pedestrians is always an inspiration. Recently I have been using a combination of brushwork and aerosol painting techniques and I am thrilled with the vibrancy of color and effects produced. Finding the connection between the visual landscape and the images the community connects with is my biggest goal during my design process.
properties.description: Monica WickelerΓÇÖs work shows full scale fox silhouettes exploring the signal box. By placing these foxes in an urban setting it reminds us that we share this space and makes us think about the co-existence of urban wildlife and people in the city.
properties.title: Monica Wickeler

properties.address: Royal York Rd & Bloor St W
properties.artist_bio: ΓÇÿElicserΓÇÖ Elliott explores narrative structures and new surfaces through the lens of more than a decade spent in the global graffiti community. A distinctive character-based practice, the work of Elicser is highly visible in cities throughout Canada, South America and South Africa. Known for his intuitive ability to capture the essence of a subject. Elicser Elliott leads the charge in the character-based movement in Toronto and was voted ΓÇÿBest Local Graffiti ArtistΓÇÖ by NOW Magazine for 2011 through 2014. His work was recently featured at the Institute for Contemporary Culture at the Royal Ontario Museum, the McMichael Canadian Art Collection, the Art Gallery of Ontario and at mural festivals in Hawaii and New York.
properties.description: The serenity and peace of the Bloor West + Royal York community was used as an inspiration for this mural
properties.title: Jabari Elliott (Elicser)

properties.artist_bio:
I would like to continue working with StART because they support the creation of art that makes our public realm a more beautiful and inviting place. StART has helped me create meaningful work that strengthens communities and enables me to develop my practice of using art as a way to build inclusive communities who celebrate their identity with pride. I would like to develop my leadership skills and am interested in mentorship opportunities where I can learn how to work more effectively with the city to realize large scale initiatives that give more artists and community members opportunities to feel empowered through the process of creating art in the public realm.

I am a Toronto based visual artist, community organizer, muralist, curator, and eternal optimist. My work is motivated by my desire to spread joy, nurture present minded living, cultivate gratitude, and foster new social interactions from a place of love and empathy. Using aerosol and acrylic paint, I work with bright colours and bold patterns to captivate peopleΓÇÖs attention and fill them with delight and hope. I am passionate about creating art that both aesthetically and psychologically brightens the streets and work to build a community around positive living.

My belief that public art is a powerful tool for building community drives my practice. In 2017, I founded Womxn Paint, an annual street art jam that has produced 44 murals celebrating the strength and diversity of womxn. I would like to continue this initiative and grow it to include additional programming that supports the professional development of womxn artists and more opportunities for young girls to learn about mural arts. In 2016, I facilitated an intergenerational mural at Baycrest Health Sciences and would like work more with the senior community.

Over the last six years, I have created custom large-scale outdoor artworks for clients including The New Yorker, Tourism Canada, the City of Toronto, the City of Mississauga, the Consulate General of the Federal Republic of Germany in Toronto, the STEPS Initiative, Arts Etobicoke, East End Arts and private clients.
properties.description: Baraket KezwarΓÇÖs smile project is about creating an alternative dialogue within public space. Her goal is to remind people to view the glass as half full. This box promotes positive messaging and art. Smile creates a space for positive conversation and seeks to remind people that life is great! The bright colours and bold patterns are eye catching and immediately uplifting.
properties.title: Baraket Kezwar

properties.address: Queen St W & St Joseph St
properties.artist_bio:
My name is Jeff Blackburn and I am a visual artist based in Toronto. With over a decade of experience producing projects for exhibition and clients, my multi-disciplinary techniques are versatile, but also maintain a recognizable style. Inspired by illustration, graffiti, and comic books, my work is known for its emphasis on line and texture, and its exploration of form using interpretive contour lines. Paintings are constructed by merging pop art aesthetics with contemporary urban art materials and techniques.

My work explores themes that revel in a flippant joie de vivre, yet remain lightly steeped in some measure of memento mori. The combined effect is one of playfully self-assured yet shadowed cheek. My compositions tend to centre on a central figure, giving the piece a definitive focal point from which the viewer can explore. The subjects of my work are chosen for their relevance to the project or location, or simply for their relevance to me. Visual impact in my murals is further accomplished through a vibrant and textured usage of colour. In these paintings, colour is freed from its formal descriptive function and displays energy and motion through a build up of spray and acrylic paint layers.

I want to continue working with StART as I have been creating projects with their team since year one, and I greatly appreciate the opportunities that theyΓÇÖve funded and helped bring to fruition for both my peers and myself.  I am hoping to grow the scale of my work in the public realm, while simultaneously gaining the key skills necessary in developing the business side of my career. With the backing of StART I have painted 14 traffic signal boxes, participated in roughly 10 StART funded mural jams, assisted American artist Andrew Schoultz in 2012 on one of the first Partnership Program murals, and most recently assisted BirdO on the first Monumental Program wall.
properties.description: Jeff BlackburnΓÇÖs designs play with the concept of nature encroaching back into urban spaces. His two boxes depict vibrant pink bears. The dynamic colours used by Blackburn bring these signal boxes to life and brighten the streetscape. The bears have a cartoonish, welcoming quality that draws the attention of those passing by.
properties.title: Jeff Blackburn

properties.artist_bio:

properties.address: Queen St W and University Ave
properties.artist_bio: Colin Turner Bloom has been involved in mural oriented community building projects since 2008 when he was 16. He was first involved in the LOFT painting program out of Christie Ossington Community Center. In 2011 Colin started his own mural company called Annex Creative Services, receiving a Youth Entrepreneurship (Summer Company) award for the business. Since 2011 through the Annex Creative Services Company Colin has produced dozens of pieces of work, predominantly murals, for a variety of private homeowners as well as commercial clients including the Miles Nadal JCC and QueenΓÇÖs University. Colin also painted four boxes as part of the 2013 and 2014 Outside the Box programs. More recently Colin had a large city theme mural on display at the AGO for a First Thursday event in 2016.
properties.description: Colin Turner-BloomΓÇÖs Canadian Shield design creates a stunning juxtaposition between the grey hues of downtown Toronto and explosion of colour present on the box itself. The bright colours used in this design will grab the attention of nearby pedestrians and draw their attention to the more subtle themes of tranquility and nature.
properties.title: Colin Turner Bloom

properties.artist_bio: Jerry Silverberg is a multi-disciplinary artist and an educator.  He has worked primarily as a print maker showing his work in galleries and cafes in around the city as well as internationally. he has illustrated for The Globe and Mail, Walrus Magazine and his work has appeared in The New York Times. Since 2011 he has completed several Light Box murals and Bell Box murals in various locations throughout the city. He has also participated with INTER-NOS, a bi annual mural project in Santiago de Cuba
properties.description: Jerry SilverbergΓÇÖs box is located across from the Royal Conservatory of Music. He chose to depict hands playing piano to acknowledge the presence of the conservatory and create synergy between the two.
properties.title: Jerry Silverberg

properties.artist_bio: ΓÇÿElicserΓÇÖ Elliott explores narrative structures and new surfaces through the lens of more than a decade spent in the global graffiti community. A distinctive character-based practice, the work of Elicser is highly visible in cities throughout Canada, South America and South Africa. Known for his intuitive ability to capture the essence of a subject. Elicser Elliott leads the charge in the character-based movement in Toronto and was voted ΓÇÿBest Local Graffiti ArtistΓÇÖ by NOW Magazine for 2011 through 2014. His work was recently featured at the Institute for Contemporary Culture at the Royal Ontario Museum, the McMichael Canadian Art Collection, the Art Gallery of Ontario and at mural festivals in Hawaii and New York.
properties.description: Elicser embraces rural town charm with a hint of wizardry just north of his 50 foot mural on the Magic Building. The approach reminds the urban dweller of the cityΓÇÖs more rural roots upon which the great city of Toronto was built. Both the farmer + the wizard are support networks for the city itself, ΓÇ£I got ya backΓÇ¥.
properties.title: Jabari Elliott (Elicser)

properties.artist_bio:
MEDIAH has proved that he can execute a mural project of this scale as he has worked with the Street Art Toronto staff for over the past five years to execute 5 large-scale, landmark art murals around the City (RADIΓÇÖAAL ENCOMPASS mural on the Woodbine/Gerrard bridge underpass, TERRA STRATΓÇÖAA bridge on the Leslie/Eglinton Ave underpass, Leslieville Bike Share mural, LANTERN SHELL murals on OΓÇÖConnor Drive, and the wrapped DRIFT APPENDAR mural for Westbury National on Warden Ave, in Scarborough). In each case, MEDIAH has proved that he can stay on schedule and within budget. He was also invited and commissioned by a Nuit Blanche curator to create a large-scale vinyl wrap installation for the 2018 Nuit BlancheΓÇÖs exhibition in Scarborough Town CentreΓÇÖs subway station and worked cooperatively with all involved. This 2018 Nuit Blanche installation was a huge success. Abroad, MEDIAH has been commissioned to paint large scale art murals all over the world in locations such as; Barbados, Brazil, Mexico, Spain, Italy, Germany, South Africa, and throughout the United States of America and Canada.

With 25 years of experience, MEDIAH has become a staple and is considered a pioneer of the Canadian street art movement. ┬¡An internationally renowned visual artist, MEDIAH is a trendsetter sparking new ideas and originality by blurring the lines between post-graffiti and dynamic abstraction. BlakeΓÇÖs work consists of weaving traditional street art forms with traditional painterly techniques. Heavily inspired by avionics, mechanical engineering, and schematics, the artwork glorifies and captures the essence of speed, motion, dynamism, and force to create movement on the image surface.

As an artist, MEDIAH strives to create visual content that inspires, intrigues and uplifts his audience. BlakeΓÇÖs past work has very rarely been vandalized or damaged due to his pedigree as an international visual artist. He has been described as ΓÇÿone of the most respected and revered graffiti artists in CanadaΓÇÖ by both vandals and street artists due to his extensive and prolific career painting large-scale murals, participating in solo and group art exhibitions, and creating immersive, cinematic video and animation productions.

His formal education in broadcast design, motion graphics, VFX and video post-production, combined with his past work experience (Fox soccer, Rogers Sportsnet, Rubberpixel, and Sinking Ship Entertainment) are pivotal to his production and project planning. MEDIAH is formally trained in Digital media and Visual Effects, allowing him to be able to document large-scale projects with cinema and broadcast quality video, graphics, and photography to create a polished package.
properties.description: MediahΓÇÖs designs compliment TorontoΓÇÖs dynamic nature. They depict both the speed and urban abstraction within the City. The boxes are meant to evoke a sense of curiosity and wonder.
properties.title: Evond Blake (Mediah)

properties.artist_bio: At the age of 14, strolling through urban jungles lit with spring sunlight, on the way back from high school I took a different route to home.Passing by another dull building, I was unexpectedly struck by richly coloured, wild and vibrant ornaments on the wall.Graffiti that fascinated me that day was a sign of love and passion for art and the beginning of my artistic journey.In Following years, getting better at graffiti I got actively involved in mural making.At 24, I entered A.R.A. Toronto and studied classical drawing and painting for 3 years, thereafter I became an apprentice to Vladimir Ribatchok and continued mastering oil painting working in the vein of contemporary realism.As an emerging artist, I work towards gaining more experience in mural making with skills I have learned over the years.
properties.description: Evgeny Cherkassov took inspiration from the ancient exotic wall murals of India. He used warm and vibrant colours which produced the cartoonish and pleasing look of the finished boxes. ThereΓÇÖs also an element of mystery in the images.
properties.title: Evgeny Cherkassov

properties.description: The shape of the signal boxes gave Emilia Jajus the idea to turn them into an antique fireplace. She used the signal boxΓÇÖs features to create 3D furnace doors. This fireplace will bring warmth to the street during TorontoΓÇÖs long winters.
properties.title: Emilia Jajus
